They do think the Lexapro has helped to some extent.

patient_descriptions.patient_statement: Doctor: When did nausea and vomiting begin?  About a few hours ago. I can't seem to stomach anything. Doctor: How many episodes of vomiting have you had?  At least four. Doctor: Any abdominal pain, fever, chill, or other symptoms?  Just nausea and vomiting.
patient_descriptions.context: Intractable nausea and vomiting.

patient_descriptions.patient_statement: Doctor: I'm going to ask you a few regular questions, okay?  Of course. Doctor: Any pain in urine?  No. Doctor: Any fever or chills?  None of them. Doctor: Did you notice any blood during urine?  No. I'm fleeing, especially when I change my positions as if I sat down to stand up so I feel that there's a certain involuntary urination. It's more like a craving. I'm charging data as every one hour in the morning, especially when I take this Lasix. Doctor: Do you apply a lot of force to the urine?  No. Doctor: How does this flow? Do you feel nothing. Doctor: Any leak in the night doesn't take place.  No.
patient_descriptions.context: The patient presents today for followup.  No dysuria, gross hematuria, fever, chills.  She continues to have urinary incontinence, especially while changing from sitting to standing position, as well as urge incontinence.  She is voiding daytime every 1 hour in the morning especially after taking Lasix, which tapers off in the afternoon, nocturia time 0.  No incontinence.  No straining to urinate.  Good stream, emptying well.  No bowel issues, however, she also indicates that while using her vaginal cream, she has difficulty doing this as she feels protrusion in the vagina, and very concerned if she has a prolapse.

patient_descriptions.patient_statement: Doctor: Have you lost weight?  No, I don't have, you can ask my daughter. Doctor: How about something like fever, nausea, vomiting, pain? Pattor: No. Doctor: And as we discussed you have problems talking and understanding. Pattor: Yes. Doctor: And you get urine infections too? Pattor: Yes. Doctor: And as discussed, your drainage is similar to past episodes when you had such an infection? Pattor: Yes.
patient_descriptions.context: As in HPI. Patient and daughter also deny weight loss, fevers, chills, sweats, nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain. She has had some difficulty expressing herself, but seems to comprehend speech as above. The patient has had a history of chronic urinary tract infections and her drainage is similar to past episodes when she has had such infection.

patient_descriptions.patient_statement: Doctor: I'm going to do a quick exam on you.  What kind of exam? Doctor: I'm just checking the lymph nodes. Every time there's an infection, these guys are the first to be noticed with the swelling. Doctor: Okay, so we'll first check your neck area. It looks good. I don't feel any inflamed lymph nodes. Your armpits also seem good and the last place to check is your groin area. It's all good. No sign of infection.
patient_descriptions.context: LYMPH: No neck, axillary or groin adenopathy was noted.

patient_descriptions.patient_statement: Doctor: Can you tell me what problems you've had in the past. Or what medical problems are going on?  You mean my heart problem and things? Doctor: Yes.  Okay, I've had hypertension and kidney problems for many years. Doctor: Okay.  I get frequent urinary infections. Doctor: Your urine creatinine is normal.  Okay. I also have severe aortic stenosis.
patient_descriptions.context: Significant for moderate to severe aortic stenosis, urinary tract infection, hypertension, chronic kidney disease (although her creatinine is near normal).

patient_descriptions.patient_statement: Doctor: So what are the stomach symptoms you feel?  I feel an intense burn in my throat. Doctor: When do you feel that? Pattor: It really hurts after eating food, especially junk food. Doctor: It's quite consistent with reflux disease. Pattor: Ah, yes. Doctor: I have the results of your survey as well, let's discuss it. Pattor: Absolutely, please, what does it show. Doctor: According to your answers, it seems that you also have depression.
patient_descriptions.context: Significant for depression and reflux disease.

patient_descriptions.patient_statement: Doctor: What is the race you identify as?  White. Doctor: Are you okay? You have a headache?  No, I have a very bad migraine. Doctor: Okay, can you indicate where you feel it most?  Here, since Monday. Doctor: Agree for most of the right frontal side and it's been forty-eight hours now?  Yes, I feel a lot of pressure. Doctor: I can understand the discomfort. Is it continuous or agitated?  He is agitated. Doctor: On the scale of one to ten, ten being the worst, how would you judge it?  Nine or more. Doctor: Have you ever experienced similar symptoms in the past?  No I didn't. Doctor: Have you hit your head buy a chance?  No. Doctor: Can you tell me if you have fever or chills, congestion, cold cough as symptoms?  No. Doctor: Have you hit your head?
patient_descriptions.context: This is a 16-year-old white female who presents here to the emergency department in a private auto with her mother for evaluation of headache.  She indicates intense constant right frontal headache, persistent since onset early on Monday, now more than 48 hours ago.  Indicates pressure type of discomfort with throbbing component.  It is as high as a 9 on a 0 to 10 scale of intensity.  She denies having had similar discomfort in the past.  Denies any trauma. Review of systems:  No fever or chills.  No sinus congestion or nasal drainage.  No cough or cold symptoms.  No head trauma.  Mild nausea.  No vomiting or diarrhea.  Other systems reviewed and are negative.

patient_descriptions.patient_statement: Doctor: Can you tell me more about your parents, please? How are they?  Thank you for asking, they're both doing well. Doctor: How old are they?  My mother is fifty years old, and my father is forty years old. Doctor: Wonderful, do you have brothers and sisters?  Yes, I have two sisters, one is a half-sister, and the other we have the same mother and dad. Doctor: How old are they?  My half-sister and I have the same mother, and she is thirty-four years old. My other sister is ten years old. Doctor: Do they have a history of diseases that you know?  My half-sister, um, no. My other sister has had yeast infections.
patient_descriptions.context: Mother is 50 and healthy.  Dad is 40 and healthy.  Half-sister, age 34, is healthy.  She has a sister who is age 10 who has some yeast infections.

patient_descriptions.patient_statement: Doctor: You have an infection that has become septic. We will have to start you with intravenous antibiotics.  Okay. Doctor: We also have to treat blood clotting. I will give you an anticoagulant to avoid any other clotting problem. Do you have any questions?  No.
patient_descriptions.context: 1.  Disseminated intravascular coagulation. 2.  Streptococcal pneumonia with sepsis.

patient_descriptions.patient_statement: Doctor: Please represent the patient's case. Guest_clinician: The patient is a man of seventy-six years of age. He complains of generalized weakness and malaise for several months. He has a history of two weeks of worsening orthostatic dizziness. He denies recent symptoms of fever or shortness of breath, cough, vomiting, diarrhoea, haemoptysia, melena, haematochia, bright red blood per rectum, polyuria, night sweats, visual changes or syncopal episodes. Doctor: You said that you feel dizzy, which makes him worse?  It's bad when I try to stay straight. I also have these intermittent headaches where he feels like someone inside. Doctor: Does these headaches change with changing positions or staying straight?  No. Doctor: Does the patient have a known medical history? Guest_clinician: Yes, he has a history.
patient_descriptions.context: This 76 y/o male complained of several months of generalized weakness and malaise, and a two week history of progressively worsening orthostatic dizziness. The dizziness worsened when moving into upright positions. In addition, he complained of intermittent throbbing holocranial headaches, which did not worsen with positional change, for the past several weeks. He had lost 40 pounds over the past year and denied any recent fever, SOB, cough, vomiting, diarrhea, hemoptysis, melena, hematochezia, bright red blood per rectum, polyuria, night sweats, visual changes, or syncopal episodes. He had a 100+ pack-year history of tobacco use and continued to smoke 1 to 2 packs per day. He has a history of sinusitis.

patient_descriptions.patient_statement: Doctor: How do you feel today, madam?  Honestly, overall, I feel much better. Doctor: Do you still have diarrhea and decreased appetite?  Yes, but I feel even better. Doctor: Have you pissed a normal amount?  Yes, no problems there. I measured it as you said to me at six hundred M. L. Doctor: When did you piss for the last time?  Hum, it was about seven this morning. Doctor: Do you have symptoms of fever?  No, I feel good enough.
patient_descriptions.context: The patient seen and examined feels better today.  Still having diarrhea, decreased appetite.  Good urine output 600 mL since 7 o'clock in the morning.  Afebrile.

patient_descriptions.patient_statement: Doctor: Your culture results have returned positive for Streptococcus pneumoniae. This is a bacterial infection. I would like to take a course in antibiotics. This should start to improve your symptoms with in three to four days.  OK. Doctor: Please let me know if your symptoms have not improved or get worse.  I'm going. Thank you.
patient_descriptions.context: Upper respiratory infection.

patient_descriptions.patient_statement: Yes, this is my mommy.
patient_descriptions.context: The patient is a 13-year-old female who had previous bilateral feet correction at 1 year of age.  Since that time, the patient has developed significant calcaneal valgus deformity with significant pain.  Radiographs confirmed collapse of the spinal arch, as well as valgus position of the foot.  Given the patient's symptoms, surgery is recommended for calcaneal osteotomy and Achilles lengthening.  Risks and benefits of surgery were discussed with the mother.  Risks of surgery include risk of anesthesia; infection; bleeding; changes in sensation in most of extremity; hardware failure; need for later hardware removal; possible nonunion; possible failure to correct all the deformity; and need for other surgical procedures.  The patient will need to be strict nonweightbearing for at least 6 weeks and wear a brace for up to 6 months.  All questions were answered and parents agreed to the above surgical plan.

patient_descriptions.patient_statement: What does that mean, doctor?
patient_descriptions.context: The patient is a 13-year-old female who had previous bilateral feet correction at 1 year of age.  Since that time, the patient has developed significant calcaneal valgus deformity with significant pain.  Radiographs confirmed collapse of the spinal arch, as well as valgus position of the foot.  Given the patient's symptoms, surgery is recommended for calcaneal osteotomy and Achilles lengthening.  Risks and benefits of surgery were discussed with the mother.  Risks of surgery include risk of anesthesia; infection; bleeding; changes in sensation in most of extremity; hardware failure; need for later hardware removal; possible nonunion; possible failure to correct all the deformity; and need for other surgical procedures.  The patient will need to be strict nonweightbearing for at least 6 weeks and wear a brace for up to 6 months.  All questions were answered and parents agreed to the above surgical plan.

patient_descriptions.patient_statement: Yes, I have a lot of pain, doctor.
patient_descriptions.context: The patient is a 13-year-old female who had previous bilateral feet correction at 1 year of age.  Since that time, the patient has developed significant calcaneal valgus deformity with significant pain.  Radiographs confirmed collapse of the spinal arch, as well as valgus position of the foot.  Given the patient's symptoms, surgery is recommended for calcaneal osteotomy and Achilles lengthening.  Risks and benefits of surgery were discussed with the mother.  Risks of surgery include risk of anesthesia; infection; bleeding; changes in sensation in most of extremity; hardware failure; need for later hardware removal; possible nonunion; possible failure to correct all the deformity; and need for other surgical procedures.  The patient will need to be strict nonweightbearing for at least 6 weeks and wear a brace for up to 6 months.  All questions were answered and parents agreed to the above surgical plan.

patient_descriptions.patient_statement: Yes, I want to get back to playing sports with my friends.
patient_descriptions.context: The patient is a 13-year-old female who had previous bilateral feet correction at 1 year of age.  Since that time, the patient has developed significant calcaneal valgus deformity with significant pain.  Radiographs confirmed collapse of the spinal arch, as well as valgus position of the foot.  Given the patient's symptoms, surgery is recommended for calcaneal osteotomy and Achilles lengthening.  Risks and benefits of surgery were discussed with the mother.  Risks of surgery include risk of anesthesia; infection; bleeding; changes in sensation in most of extremity; hardware failure; need for later hardware removal; possible nonunion; possible failure to correct all the deformity; and need for other surgical procedures.  The patient will need to be strict nonweightbearing for at least 6 weeks and wear a brace for up to 6 months.  All questions were answered and parents agreed to the above surgical plan.

patient_descriptions.patient_statement: Doctor: You have nausea, vomiting?  Yes to both. Doctor: How about fever?  Yes, I do. Doctor: No blood in sputum or chest pain?  Yes, I do.
patient_descriptions.context: Ten-system review significant for nausea, vomiting, fever, hemoptysis, and pleuritic chest pain.

patient_descriptions.patient_statement: Doctor: How long do you have this cough?  Three weeks past, Doc. Doc.: Do you raise something when you cough?  No. Doctor: Any shortness of breath or chest pain?  No. Doctor: How about fevers or chills?  None of this.
patient_descriptions.context: Otherwise negative for any recent febrile illnesses, chest pains or shortness of breath.

patient_descriptions.patient_statement: Doctor: Tell me about your medical history.  I was diagnosed with stage three ovarian cancer two years ago. They found a tumor in my upper abdomen. I underwent surgery and they removed everything. Dr. King is my oncologist. Doctor: Are you still under treatment?  Yes. Doctor: Do you have any other medical problems?  Do you have a heart murmuring. It was not a problem. I also have acid reflux. Doctor: Do you take any medicine for G E R D?  Yes. I am taking omeprazole.
patient_descriptions.context: 1. Gastroesophageal reflux disease. 2. Mitral valve prolapse. 3. Stage IIIC papillary serous adenocarcinoma of the ovaries.

patient_descriptions.patient_statement: I didn't have any nasal infections. Here's my report from my previous doctor who sent me back to you. Thank you. Let me look. I see here that you had severe sinusitis two to three months ago, is that correct?  Is that what they call my nasal problems? Doctor: Yes, it is true. Sinusitis is the inflammation of your nasal airways.  I see. Thank you for describing it to me.  No problem. Could you describe to me what you felt two to three months ago?  Yes, I can. My face would be uncomfortable, my nose was stifled, my eyes hurt, and I felt something you left in the back of my throat.  Have you ever received any medicines?
patient_descriptions.context: I had the pleasure of meeting and evaluating the patient referred today for evaluation and treatment of chronic sinusitis.  As you are well aware, she is a pleasant 50-year-old female who states she started having severe sinusitis about two to three months ago with facial discomfort, nasal congestion, eye pain, and postnasal drip symptoms.  She states she really has sinus problems, but this infection has been rather severe and she notes she has not had much improvement with antibiotics.  She had a CT of her paranasal sinuses identifying mild mucosal thickening of right paranasal sinuses with occlusion of the ostiomeatal complex on the right and turbinate hypertrophy was also noted when I reviewed the films and there is some minimal nasal septum deviation to the left.  She currently is not taking any medication for her sinuses.  She also has noted that she is having some problems with her balance and possible hearing loss or at least ear popping and fullness.  Her audiogram today demonstrated mild high frequency sensorineural hearing loss, normal tympanometry, and normal speech discrimination.  She has tried topical nasal corticosteroid therapy without much improvement.  She tried Allegra without much improvement and she believes the Allegra may have caused problems with balance to worsen.  She notes her dizziness to be much worse if she does quick positional changes such as head turning or sudden movements, no ear fullness, pressure, humming, buzzing or roaring noted in her ears.  She denies any previous history of sinus surgery or nasal injury.  She believes she has some degree of allergy symptoms.

patient_descriptions.patient_statement: Doctor: Do you still take Micronase every morning?  Yes, I take um two points five M G once a day. Doctor: Great. Keep taking Micronase by mouth every day. As for your infection, I want you to start taking Bactrim twice a day. I will prescribe thirty pills. It will be Bactrim four hundred M G and eighty M G tablets.
patient_descriptions.context: Micronase 2.5 mg Tab PO QAM #30.  Bactrim 400/80 Tab PO BID #30.

patient_descriptions.patient_statement: Doctor: I think three weeks ago for recurrent urinary infections. Doctor: Yes, it says here that you have bladder problems for a long time, mainly related to tone and ability.  Yes, that's why they put me in catheter. Doctor: Okay and you have recently had the right side C V A?  Yes, because of my heart problems, they had to put pacemaker in it. Doctor: Okay.  I have hereditary diabetes. Doctor: Okay and your neuronal problem is also associated with that.  That's true.  You have pains on the right side now?  Yes, because of my stroke. Doctor: And you are also taking thyroid medications?  Yes, for my hypothyroidism. Doctor: Ok.  Yes.  What procedures have you had in the past?  I have had many exact surgerys. They've taken my bladder, and now they've been put out of the biliary bladder.
patient_descriptions.context: Significant for recurrent UTIs as she was recently to the hospital about 3 weeks ago for urinary tract infection.  She has chronic incontinence and bladder atony, for which eventually it was decided for the care of the patient to put a Foley catheter and leave it in place.  She has had right-sided CVA.  She has had atrial fibrillation status post pacemaker.  She is a type 2 diabetic with significant neuropathy.  She has also had significant pain on the right side from her stroke.  She has a history of hypothyroidism.  Past surgical history is significant for cholecystectomy, colon cancer surgery in 1998.  She has had a pacemaker placement.

patient_descriptions.patient_statement: Doctor: Can you tell me more about your son, please? Guest_family: Well, he's seven years old, and he's had diarrhea for four days, and he's been vomiting for three days.  Yes, my brother did this too. Guest_family: We had a little chicken one day, and then we had more of it the next day. After they ate they started to feel bad and still feel bad. Doctor: How many times did he have diarrhea a day from that beginning? Guest_family: Well, it was about five or six times a day during the last four days. Doctor: How many times did he vomit a day? Guest_family: Um, it was frequent. Doctor: Has he vomited today?  No, I didn't have it today. Doctor: Did he go to the bathroom today?  Yes, I pissed this morning. Doctor: He had symptoms of fever?
patient_descriptions.context: The patient is a 7-year-old male who comes in today with a three-day history of emesis and a four-day history of diarrhea.  Apparently, his brother had similar symptoms.  They had eaten some chicken and then ate some more of it the next day, and I could not quite understand what the problem was because there is a little bit of language barrier, although dad was trying very hard to explain to me what had happened.  But any way, after he and his brother got done eating with chicken, they both felt bad and have continued to feel bad.  The patient has had diarrhea five to six times a day for the last four days and then he had emesis pretty frequently three days ago and then has just had a couple of it each day in the last two days.  He has not had any emesis today.  He has urinated this morning.  His parents are both concerned because he had a fever of 103 last night.  Also, he ate half of a hamburger yesterday and he tried drinking some milk and that is when he had an emesis.  He has been drinking Pedialyte, Gatorade, white grape juice, and 7Up, otherwise he has not been eating anything.

patient_descriptions.patient_statement: Doctor: Welcome to the clinic! I would like to start with your medical history.  I have high blood pressure and macular deterioration. Last year I caught pneumonia but it became clear. Doctor: Okay. What brings you today?  I had this cough and pain on the right side of my abdomen. Doctor: How long did it last?  Two days. I had bodily pain and felt sick too. Doctor: Did you have a fever?  I think so. I was cold and my forehead was hot. The cough is a dry cough. Doctor: Did abdominal pain occur during one of these cough episodes?  Yes.
patient_descriptions.context: This is a 76-year-old female who has a history of previous pneumonia, also hypertension and macular degeneration, who presents with generalized body aches, cough, nausea, and right-sided abdominal pain for two days.  The patient stated that the abdominal pain was only associated with coughing.  The patient reported that the cough is dry in nature and the patient had subjective fevers and chills at home.

patient_descriptions.patient_statement: Doctor: What brings you today?  My back started to hurt last night. I have stomach pain. I have had pain with urination for two days. Doctor: Do you have any other symptoms?  I just coughed and now I have fever. Doctor: Do you have a history of kidney stones?  Yes. I had kidney stones less than a year ago. I had a urinary infection at the same time. It was horrible.
patient_descriptions.context: The patient complains of backache, stomachache, and dysuria for the last two days.  Fever just started today and cough.  She has history of kidney stones less than a year ago and had a urinary tract infection at that time.  Her back started hurting last night.

patient_descriptions.patient_statement: Doctor: You are here today because you have difficulties of vision? Tell me what is happening, madame.  Yes. It all started a year ago. It started with losing color in my vision. Doctor: Was the loss sudden or progressive?  Gradual. And now I'm starting to have a blurred vision. Doctor: When did this start?  I noticed it two months ago. Doctor: Is the blurred vision all blurred or is there a blind angle of blurred vision.  It's a blurred vision and then I have a blind angle in my right eye. Doctor: Have you had any fluctuations of your symptoms over the last year? Do you have a vision back?  Some days, I feel like a little better, but not much.
patient_descriptions.context: 58 y/o female presents with a one year history of progressive loss of color vision. In the past two months she has developed blurred vision and a central scotoma OD. There are no symptoms of photopsias, diplopia, headache, or eye pain. There are no other complaints. There have been mild fluctuations of her symptoms, but her vision has never returned to its baseline prior to symptom onset one year ago.

patient_descriptions.patient_statement: Doctor: I stayed relatively the same. My main complaint is that I feel tired throughout the day. The C P A P is doing well and I wake up refreshed, but I don't like how I crash. Doctor: Okay. How are the thyroid problems?  I seem to be fine. My thyroid gland doesn't seem enlarged and I can breathe as normal. No fever or anything. Doctor: Have you experienced any of the following situations: temperature intolerance, palpitations, muscle weakness, tremors, nausea, vomiting, constipation or diarrhoea?  Nothing like it. Doctor: How was the weight?  He was stable. Doctor: Any muscle weakness closest to the center of the body?  No, nothing at all. Not bad for forty-five.
patient_descriptions.context: This is a return visit to the endocrine clinic for the patient with history as noted above.  She is 45 years old.  Her last visit was about 6 months ago.  Since that time, the patient states her health has remained unchanged.  Currently, primary complaint is one of fatigue that she feels throughout the day.  She states, however, she is doing well with CPAP and wakes up feeling refreshed but tends to tire out later in the day.  In terms of her thyroid issues, the patient states that she is not having signs or symptoms of thyroid excess or hypothyroidism.  She is not reporting temperature intolerance, palpitations, muscle weakness, tremors, nausea, vomiting, constipation, hyperdefecation or diarrhea.  Her weight has been stable.  She is not reporting proximal muscle weakness.

patient_descriptions.patient_statement: I think this is our first meeting.  Hello, doctor. Yes, this is my first time. Doctor: Great, how old are you?  I am fifty-five years old, doctor. Doctor: Thank you, what seems to be the problem today?  Well, I have a list of the symptoms of laundry coinciding with my allergies. Doctor: Like what, ma'am?  Well, my sense of taste is diminished, dry mouth, um, acid reflux, and G I problems, and then I have asthma, and reactions to things like aerosols. Doctor: I see, do you have food allergies?  Hum, I think.
patient_descriptions.context: A 55-year-old female presents self-referred for the possibility of evaluation and treatment of allergies, diminished taste, xerostomia, gastroesophageal reflux disease, possible food allergies, chronic GI irritability, asthma, and environmental inhalant allergies.  Please refer to chart for history and physical and review of systems and detailed medical history.

patient_descriptions.patient_statement: No sudden gain or loss of weight?  No. Doctor: No headache, bleeding of the nose, coarse voice, blurred vision or loss of vision.  No, not at all. Doctor: No fever or chills, not at all.  No fever or anything.  No pain in the chest, shortness of breath or shortness of breath during sleep?  No palpitation, swelling or varicose veins or pain in the legs?  No pain in the throat or cough or cough with mucous membrane or sputum?  I have this cough prolonged, but not anything.  No breathing?  No wheezing.  No heart burn, nausea or vomiting?  No pain in the stool or urine?  No pain in the back or abdominal pain?  No pain in the back or back.  No pain in the back.  No pain in the back.
patient_descriptions.context: CONSTITUTIONAL:  Denies weight loss/gain, fever or chills. ENMT:  Denies headaches, nosebleeds, voice changes, blurry vision or changes in/loss of vision. CV:  See history of present illness.  Denies chest pain, SOB supine, palpitations, edema, varicose veins or leg pains. RESPIRATORY:  He has a chronic cough.  Denies shortness of breath, wheezing, sputum production or bloody sputum. GI:  Denies heartburn, blood in stools, loss of appetite, abdominal pain or constipation. GU:  Denies painful/burning urination, cloudy/dark urine, flank pain or groin pain. MS:  Denies joint pain/stiffness, backaches, tendon/ligaments/muscle pains/strains, bone aches/pains or muscle weakness. NEURO:  Denies blackouts, seizures, loss of memory, hallucinations, weakness, numbness, tremors or paralysis. PSYCH:  Denies anxiety, irritability, apathy, depression, sleep disturbances, appetite disturbances or suicidal thoughts. INTEGUMENTARY:  Denies unusual hair loss/breakage, skin lesions/discoloration or unusual nail breakage/discoloration.

patient_descriptions.patient_statement: Doctor: All right, but tell me what's going on and we can understand that.  Okay, so my right hand and my left foot were very swollen and very painful, and that's why I came to the emergency room. Doctor: Do you have a bag of urine?  Yes, I couldn't go for them to put it in. Doctor: Yes, it seems that five hundred ML have come out. So much possible urinary obstruction. Also, they started you on steroids and colchicin. How do you feel now?  I feel a little better, my pain is getting better, and the swelling is getting better. Doctor: Okay, that's good. Any fever and chills? Pattor: No, no fever. Doctor: Any urine problem like pain or frequency or blood in the urine?  No, but I'm not able to empty my bladder well, the pipi has decreased a lot, I couldn't urinate. Doctor: All right, I'll evaluate that.
patient_descriptions.context: The patient denies any complaints, states that the right hand and left foot was very swollen and very painful, and came to emergency room.  Also, she could not urinate and states as soon as they put Foley in, 500 mL of urine came out.  Also they started her on steroids and colchicine, and the pain is improving and the swelling is getting better.  Denies any fever and chills.  Denies any dysuria, frequency or hematuria.  States that the urine output was decreased considerably, and she could not urinate.  Denies any cough, hemoptysis or sputum production.  Denies any chest pain, orthopnea or paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea.

patient_descriptions.patient_statement: Doctor: Okay.  I have nothing else. Doctor: Okay, no fever, no nausea, nothing like that?  No.
patient_descriptions.context: Significant for pain in the buttock.  Otherwise negative.

patient_descriptions.patient_statement: Doctor: Hello, ma'am. Can you confirm your age for me?  Well, doctor, I am now sixty-six years old. Doctor: Thank you, how is your knee going today? Let's hope that the osteoarthritis improves.  It's so bad, doctor. Doctor: Have you had any improvements with the rest and anti-inflammatorys we talked about before?  No, they didn't help at all. Doctor: I see, you would be a good candidate for knee replacement.  What is the risk of surgery infection? Doctor: Historically, it's less than one percent, we use prophylaxis antibiotics to control infection all the time.  Great, and will I sleep for that? Doctor: Yes, you won't feel anything.
patient_descriptions.context: A 66-year-old female with knee osteoarthrosis.  Failed conservative management.  Risks and benefits of different treatment options were explained.  Informed consent was obtained.

patient_descriptions.patient_statement: Doctor: So I see you were diagnosed with acid reflux and high blood pressure 20 years ago?  Yes. Doctor: And then you also have arthritis and Parkinson's.  Yes, both. Doctor: Also, you had a cerebral stroke?  Yes, mini-AVC! Doctor: Ah, yes. We also call him T I A.  OK. Doctor: And now you're taking medication?  Just Coumadin, for my chronicle A Fib. I've been there for three years. Doctor: Yes, atrial fibrillation.  Yes.
patient_descriptions.context: GERD, hypertension times 20 years, arthritis, Parkinson's, TIA, chronic atrial fibrillation, on Coumadin three years.

patient_descriptions.patient_statement: Doctor: Hello, young man.  Hello, doctor. Doctor: How old are you, sir?  I'm thirteen years old. Doctor: What brings you today? Guest_family: Well, at the beginning we went to Sierra Pacific Orthopaedic Group, and he had an MR that I showed, um, O C D in the left knee. Doctor: Yes, I see that in the report. Guest_family: So we're here for a second opinion on this. Doctor: Yes, we should do surgery on this knee. There's a serious instability of the fragment, and we don't want that to get worse. Guest_family: Ok, that's about what we've heard so far. What are the risks of infection of the procedure? Doctor: It's less than one percent. We use antibiotics to control the infection.
patient_descriptions.context: The patient is 13-year-old male with persistent left knee pain.  He was initially seen at Sierra Pacific Orthopedic Group where an MRI demonstrated unstable OCD lesion of the left knee.  The patient presented here for a second opinion.  Surgery was recommended grossly due to the instability of the fragment.  Risks and benefits of surgery were discussed.  The risks of surgery include risk of anesthesia, infection, bleeding, changes in sensation and motion extremity, failure to relieve pain or restore the articular cartilage, possible need for other surgical procedures, and possible early arthritis.  All questions were answered and parents agreed to the above plan.

patient_descriptions.patient_statement: Yes, I always knew how to speak English before I was even a teenager. So, when I moved to America, I didn't have a language problem. Doctor: Okay and did you move with your family?  No, my family moved to the eastern side of Germany that was occupied by Russia at that time, but I decided to move to America in nineteen fifty-seven years.  I had a high school diploma from Germany, and I could speak German and English fluently.  As soon as I landed here in America, I started working. I started as a secretary in a private company and later I worked at I B M. Now I am retired for almost twenty years because of my complications of cancer. Doctor: Your Mesothelioma?  Yes. Doctor: Okay, and who are all there in your family?  I am alone without a companion. I am a son who lives in Santa Cruz, he doesn't drink a lot.
patient_descriptions.context: Significant for her being without a companion at this point.  She was born in Munich, Germany.  She immigrated to of America in 1957 after her family had to move to Eastern Germany, which was under Russian occupation at that time.  She is divorced.  She used to work as a secretary and later worked as a clerical worker at IBM.  She stopped working more than 20 years ago due to complications from her mesothelioma.  She denies any significant tobacco, alcohol or illicit drugs.  She is bilingual speaking, German and English.  She has known English from before her teens.  She has the equivalent of a high school education in Germany.  She has one brother and one sister, both of whom are healthy and she does not spend much time communicating with them.  She has one son who lives in Santa Cruz.  He has grandchildren.  She is trying to contact with her grandchildren.

patient_descriptions.patient_statement: Doctor: When did you take your temperature for the last time?  Just before I drive here. Doctor: I see. Did the nurse take your temperature when you entered?  Yes, she did. Doctor: Did you experience a cold like symptoms such as cough, nasal congestion, headache or nausea?  No, not really. Doctor: Did you try to take a medication to help with fever?  Yes. I took Tylenol and it helped a little. Doctor: Have you had any recent sick contacts?  I don't think so. I live with three other roommates and they seem good.
patient_descriptions.context: Fever of unknown origin.

patient_descriptions.patient_statement: Doctor: I am forty-nine years old, and I identify myself as white. Doctor: Thank you. What brought you today?  I was referred to you so that I could have everything that goes wrong with me under control. Doctor: I see. What is going on?  I have a pain in my back of my leg this year when I was in A B C D. Doctor: What part of your leg?  The back of my left thigh. Doctor: I see. Just the leg?  I also have a pain in my knee of a boat when I was out fishing with water. Doctor: Was it serious?  It was a complete spectacle. A helicopter came down and threw me to X Y Z infections?
patient_descriptions.context: This is a 49-year-old white male who sustained a traumatic injury to his left posterior thighthis past year while in ABCD.  He sustained an injury from the patellar from a boat while in the water.  He was air lifted actually up to XYZ Hospital and underwent extensive surgery.  He still has an external fixation on it for the healing fractures in the leg and has undergone grafting and full thickness skin grafting closure to a large defect in his left posterior thigh, which is nearly healed right in the gluteal fold on that left area.  In several areas right along the graft site and low in the leg, the patient has several areas of hypergranulation tissue.  He has some drainage from these areas.  There are no signs and symptoms of infection.  He is referred to us to help him get those areas under control.

patient_descriptions.patient_statement: Doctor: Doctor X has sent you back to us, is that correct?  Yes. He is my primary care doctor. Doctor: It seems that you have a birthday to come. Happy birthday!  Thank you. Yes, I'm going to be seventy-seven years old. Doctor: Dr. Kim's notes say you had pain in your left flank. Can you tell me more about the pain?  Yes. The pain started four or five days ago. He was in my stomach and back on my left side. Here. Doctor: Okay. Did you have nausea or vomiting?  Yes. I had nausea, and I vomited a few times. Doctor: Did you notice any blood, pain and/or burns during urination?  No. Doctor: Any fever or chills?  No. Doctor: I have the ultrasound results that Dr. X ordered the other day.
patient_descriptions.context: The patient is a 76-year-old female who was referred to us from Dr. X for left flank pain.  The patient was found to have a left ureteral stone measuring about 1.3 cm in size per the patient's history.  The patient has had pain in the abdomen and across the back for the last four to five days.  The patient has some nausea and vomiting.  The patient wants something done for the stone.  The patient denies any hematuria, dysuria, burning or pain.  The patient denies any fevers.

patient_descriptions.patient_statement: I also noticed a new rash on my right calf. Doctor: Can you describe what kind of dizziness you have? What are they feeling?  It's general dizziness and dizziness. I'm also dizzy during episodes. Doctor: Are you feeling well now or are you feeling symptoms?  I have headaches and randomity, but nothing now. Neck pain and muscle pain are also intermittent. Doctor: Let me look at the rash on your legs. Are the bruises new?  They are new, I think. I noticed them more than usual. Doctor: In the last few days you had fever or chills?  No, nothing like that. Doctor: What is chest pain?  I had a little tightness in my chest, but not now.
patient_descriptions.context: The patient is in complaining of headaches and dizzy spells, as well as a new little rash on the medial right calf.  She describes her dizziness as both vertigo and lightheadedness.  She does not have a headache at present but has some intermittent headaches, neck pains, and generalized myalgias.  She has noticed a few more bruises on her legs.  No fever or chills with slight cough.  She has had more chest pains but not at present.  She does have a little bit of nausea but no vomiting or diarrhea.  She complains of some left shoulder tenderness and discomfort.  She reports her blood sugar today after lunch was 155.

patient_descriptions.patient_statement: Doctor: Your chest x ray showed diffuse pulmonary edema. This means that you have fluid in your lungs. This would explain your chest pain and difficulties with your breathing. I would like to start with a course of antibiotics to prevent any possible infection. I will also send a prescription for Furosemide. This will reduce the accumulation of fluid in your lungs. Do you have any questions?  When should I begin to feel better? Doctor: You should start to feel better within three to five days.
patient_descriptions.context: Chest x-ray revealed a diffuse pulmonary edema.

patient_descriptions.patient_statement: I'm here for this pain in my legs. It hurts especially in the night. Doctor: Does changing your position help you?  Yes, it helps. Every time I'm standing, it just leaves. Doctor: Is it only in your legs where it starts there and goes elsewhere too?  Normally starts in my hips and then it goes down my leg and sometimes in my ankles too. Doctor: When did you notice a first?  Everything started after taking this medication. What does he call? Something with L? Yes, Lipitor. Doctor: Have you ever noticed night sweats?  Sometimes I sweat at night. Doctor: Any other problem? Your body temperature is a little on the upper end. Patients: Yes, I feel feverish and nausea too. Doctor: How are your sugars?  They have been low for a while.
patient_descriptions.context: This is a 56-year-old female who has pain in her legs at nighttime and when she gets up it comes and goes, radiates from her buttocks to her legs, sometimes it is her ankle.  She has noticed it since she has been on Lipitor.  She has had some night sweats occasionally.  She has had a little bit of fever and nausea.  She has noticed her blood sugars have been low.  She has lost over 30 pounds after exercising doing water aerobics at Genesis in Wichita.  She has noticed her fasting blood sugars have been ranging from 100 to 120.  Blood sugars one and a half hours after meals have been 185.  She is coming in for a diabetic checkup in one month and wants lab prior to that time.  She has been eating more meat recently and has not been on a diet for cholesterol.

patient_descriptions.patient_statement: I'm Dr. Smith.  Hello! It's nice to meet you. Doctor: Let's start with your family medical history.  My mother had breast cancer. My father had lung cancer that ended up taking his life. He was seventy years old when he died. My mother also died but not of an illness but of an infection that she had after having had elective surgery. Doctor: I'm so sorry for your loss. How old was your mother when she died?  Thank you. She was eighty years old when she died. I'm an orphan now. My only alive brother died at the age of forty. He had a difficult life. He had a mental illness. Doctor: How did your brother die?  He had pancreatitis. Oh, my father had glaucoma. Doctor: You had a lot of loss.  Yes, I have. My good friend died a year and a half ago.
patient_descriptions.context: Father died from CA at the age of 79.  Mother died from postoperative infection at the age of 81.  Brother died from pancreatitis at the age of 40 and had a prior history of mental illness.  Father also had a prior history of lung cancer.  Mother had a history of breast cancer.  Father also had glaucoma.  He does not have any living siblings.  Friend died a year and half ago.

patient_descriptions.patient_statement: Hm
patient_descriptions.context: A 47-year-old Latin American man presented to the emergency room after being told to come in for a high potassium value drawn the previous day. He had gone to an outside clinic the day prior to presentation complaining of weakness and fatigue. Labs drawn there revealed a potassium of 7.0 and he was told to come here for further evaluation. At time of his assessment in the emergency room, he noted general malaise and fatigue for eight months. Over this same time period he had subjective fevers and chills, night sweats, and a twenty-pound weight loss. He described anorexia with occasional nausea and vomiting of non-bilious material along with a feeling of light-headedness that occurred shortly after standing from a sitting or lying position. He denied a productive cough but did note chronic left sided upper back pain located in the ribs that was worse with cough and better with massage. He denied orthopnea or paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea but did become dyspneic after walking 2-3 blocks where before he had been able to jog 2-3 miles. He also noted that over the past year his left testicle had been getting progressively more swollen and painful. He had been seen for this at the onset of symptoms and given a course of antibiotics without improvement. Over the last several months there had been chronic drainage of yellowish material from this testicle. He denied trauma to this area. He denied diarrhea or constipation, changes in his urinary habits, rashes or skin changes, arthritis, arthralgias, abdominal pain, headache or visual changes.

patient_descriptions.patient_statement: Well, I am forty seven and would proudly call myself as Latin American.

Over this same time period he had subjective fevers and chills, night sweats, and a twenty-pound weight loss. He described anorexia with occasional nausea and vomiting of non-bilious material along with a feeling of light-headedness that occurred shortly after standing from a sitting or lying position. He denied a productive cough but did note chronic left sided upper back pain located in the ribs that was worse with cough and better with massage. He denied orthopnea or paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea but did become dyspneic after walking 2-3 blocks where before he had been able to jog 2-3 miles. He also noted that over the past year his left testicle had been getting progressively more swollen and painful. He had been seen for this at the onset of symptoms and given a course of antibiotics without improvement. Over the last several months there had been chronic drainage of yellowish material from this testicle. He denied trauma to this area. He denied diarrhea or constipation, changes in his urinary habits, rashes or skin changes, arthritis, arthralgias, abdominal pain, headache or visual changes.

patient_descriptions.patient_statement: I also have chills. Doctor: Did you take anything for fever?  Tylenol and Advil. I take them interchangeably. Doctor: When did you take your temperature for the last time?  An hour ago. The thermometer read an O one point four. Doctor: Do you feel any other symptoms, such as shortness of breath, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, or others?  I had a stronger desire to pee much more than usual.  I don't know if it's related.  It could be. We still wait on your urine results. Do you have a history of cataracts or glaucoma?  No. Doctor: Very good. Any signs of pneumonia or valley fever?  Nothing like that.
patient_descriptions.context: CONSTITUTIONAL:  No history of fever, rigors, or chills except for recent fever and rigors. HEENT:  No history of cataract or glaucoma. RESPIRATORY:  Shortness of breath.  No pneumonia or valley fever. GASTROINTESTINAL:  Nausea and vomiting.  No hematemesis or melena. UROLOGICAL:  Frequency, urgency. MUSCULOSKELETAL:  No muscle weakness. SKIN:  None significant. NEUROLOGICAL:  No TIA or CVA.  No seizure disorder. PSYCHOLOGICAL:  No anxiety or depression.  HEMATOLOGICAL:  None significant.

patient_descriptions.patient_statement: Doctor: Your prescription is two hundred MG twice a day, that's it. Doctor: Do you have a report on your eyes with you today?  Yes, doctor. That's it. Doctor: Well, thank you, what's the problem today?  Well, I have some pain in my hands and elbows. Doctor: When did you start this pain?  It's been a few weeks now. Doctor: Is there a related trauma? Did you fall?  No, no falls or anything. It just started one day, and it really bothers me. Doctor: Do you have fever or chills, or symptoms of cold or flu like that?  No, I'm not. Doctor: How do you get a swelling? Are your joints swollen?  No, everything is normal there.
patient_descriptions.context: The patient is here for a follow-up.  The patient has a history of lupus, currently on Plaquenil 200-mg b.i.d.  Eye report was noted and appreciated.  The patient states that she is having some aches and pains of the hands and elbows that started recently a few weeks ago.  She denied having any trauma.  She states that the pain is bothering her.  She denies having any fevers, chills, or any joint effusion or swelling at this point.  She noted also that there is some increase in her hair loss in the recent times.

patient_descriptions.patient_statement: Doctor: Are you fired for a right abdominal infection?  Yes, they told me I could have C Diff? Doctor: Yes that's why we're going to evaluate you.
patient_descriptions.context: I was asked to see the patient for C. diff colitis.

patient_descriptions.patient_statement: Doctor: Have you had a recent vaccination?  I had an influenza vaccine last winter but I didn't have and recent vaccines. Doctor: Did you plan anything in the near future?  I was going to have another influenza vaccine but I don't think I'm due for that for another three months. Doctor: Super.
patient_descriptions.context: Nothing significant.

patient_descriptions.patient_statement: Doctor: Very well, and just to remind you, you had a withdrawal of the Ex Fix from the right knee with a M U A following O R I F of a fracture of the right tibial plateau.  Yes, it looks familiar. What is M U A? Doctor: This is manipulation under anesthesia. We folded the knee in order to break by force some scar tissue.  Oh, wow. Doctor: Yes, it's great, eliminates a certain need for P T in fact. How do you do it today?  Overall, my pain is under control. Doctor: You have an influenza like, or symptoms of infection?  No, nothing like that. Doctor: So, no fever, or chills, or sweating during the night.  Yes, nothing like that. Doctor: Super. I see you have no drainage of the pining sites, but it doesn't bother me too much. Pattor: Ok, good, no sweat.
patient_descriptions.context: The patient is now approximately week status post removal of Ex-Fix from the right knee with an MUA following open reduction internal fixation of right tibial plateau fracture.  The patient states that this pain is well controlled.  He has had no fevers, chills or night sweats.  He has had some mild drainage from his pin sites.  He just started doing range of motion type exercises for his right knee.  He has had no numbness or tingling.

patient_descriptions.patient_statement: I am forty-three years old and this is the first time that I have had a major problem. It is only this month that I have felt weaker than usual. I am much tireder and short of breath every time I move. Doctor: Recent weight loss?  Yes, I have lost about fifteen pounds in less than two or three months. Doctor: How is your appetite? Nausea, vomiting, diarrhoea?  The appetite is good enough. No nausea, vomiting, or diarrhea. Doctor: How is fever, chills, sweating, cough?  No, ma'am. Doctor: And all chest pain with your breathlessness?  No, ma'am.
patient_descriptions.context: This is a 43-year-old black man with no apparent past medical history who presented to the emergency room with the chief complaint of weakness, malaise and dyspnea on exertion for approximately one month.  The patient also reports a 15-pound weight loss.  He denies fever, chills and sweats.  He denies cough and diarrhea.  He has mild anorexia.

patient_descriptions.patient_statement: Doctor: I had a headache all week with the neck and the pain of the lower back. Doctor: How would you describe the headache?  Is it constant?  He comes and goes for the most part. Doctor: How would you judge him on a scale of ten with ten being the worst?  One seven or eight. Doctor: Do you have a headache now?  No, not well this second. Doctor: Did you take -  Nothing for pain? Doctor: Yes.  I took a little Ibuprofen, but it does not seem to help much. Doctor: Any other symptoms associated with headaches, such as fever, chills, nausea, vomiting, blurred vision or sensitivity to light?  No, not really.
patient_descriptions.context: Headache and pain in the neck and lower back.

patient_descriptions.patient_statement: Doctor: Do you have a history of rheumatic fever during your childhood?  No. Doctor: A history of other usual childhood diseases?  No.
patient_descriptions.context: Negative for rheumatic fever.  The patient has usual childhood illnesses.

patient_descriptions.patient_statement: Doctor: You have observed blood in your stools or in your vomiting?  No, nothing like that.  No, nothing like that.  Okay, well. Have you noticed an increase in your frequency of urine or your emergency?  No. Doctor: Do you feel muscle weakness or fatigue?  No, nothing like that.  None of the known history of arthritis?  No.  And no fever due to fungal infection or something, is it not?  No, nothing like that.  None of the history of pneumonia?  No.  And I am looking at your record, so no antecedents of stroke, C V A, or a convulsive disorder.  That's right.  No problem related to thyroid or hormone?  No. Doctor: And you have no blood problems, that's correct.  No problem with thyroid or hormone.
patient_descriptions.context: CONSTITUTIONAL:  No history of fever, rigors, or chills. HEENT:  No history of cataract, blurring vision, or glaucoma.  RESPIRATORY:  Shortness of breath.  No pneumonia or valley fever. GASTROINTESTINAL:  No epigastric discomfort, hematemesis, or melena. UROLOGICAL:  No frequency or urgency. MUSCULOSKELETAL:  No arthritis or muscle weakness. CNS:  No TIA.  No CVA.  No seizure disorder. ENDOCRINE:  Nonsignificant. HEMATOLOGICAL:  Nonsignificant.

patient_descriptions.patient_statement: Doctor: So, what brings you here today?  Well, I have a lot of medical problems and I see Doctor X for them, but I wanted a second opinion, so he sent me back here. Doctor: Yes, he's a good man! Don't worry, we'll take care of you.  Thank you. Doctor: So, let me start by getting your medical history.  Of course, I had skin cancer that was treated by the withdrawal of this part. Doctor: Ok.  Other than that, I have an anaemia and an acid reflux problem. I also have a history of C O P D. Doctor: Very well.  I also suffer from sciatica that was caused mainly by my arthritis. Doctor: I see.
patient_descriptions.context: The patient has multiple medical problems, for which she is under the care of Dr. X.  She has a history of chronic obstructive lung disease and a history of gastroesophageal reflux disease.  There is a history of anemia and there is a history of sciatica, which has been caused by arthritis.  The patient has had skin cancers, which have been treated with local excision.

patient_descriptions.patient_statement: Doctor: What is the problem today, sir?  When is the pain the worst?  Honestly, it starts with the first stage of the morning. Doctor: Does it get worse throughout the day?  Yes, it gets worse all day with activities.  What treatments have you had for that?  Well, nothing to this day.  Where is your heel pain?  It's on the right heel, then it's on the lower part of the heel and inside the heel.  Have you changed your medical history since your last visit?  No, it's the same old as you.  Do you have symptoms like flu?  Like fever or chills?  This, or vomiting or headache?  No, it's the same old doctor as you.
patient_descriptions.context: Mr. Sample Patient returns to the Sample Clinic with the chief complaint of painful right heel.  The patient states that the heel has been painful for approximately two weeks, it is starts with the first step in the morning and gets worse with activity during the day.  The patient states that he is currently doing no treatment for it.  He states that most of his pain is along medial tubercle of the right calcaneus and extends to the medial arch.  The patient states that he has no change in the past medical history since his last visit and denies any fever, chills, vomiting, headache, chest, or shortness of breath.

patient_descriptions.patient_statement: Doctor: Before you start, can I ask you how old you are?  Hello, doctor. I am fifty-six years old, now. Doctor: Great, thank you. What is the problem today, madam?  Well, I need some support for food recommendations for a healthy diet for my husband and me. Doctor: Why would that be, madam?  Hum, I have a lot to do, high cholesterol, high blood pressure, acid reflux, and I just want to lose weight. My husband also has a high cholesterol level. Doctor: Tell me more about your eating habits, please.  Well, we live alone now that our children are gone, but I'm used to cooking very large portions. Doctor: Do you have trouble doing food for only two people?  Yes, that's a good way to say it.
patient_descriptions.context: This is a 56-year-old female who comes in for a dietary consultation for hyperlipidemia, hypertension, gastroesophageal reflux disease and weight reduction.  The patient states that her husband has been diagnosed with high blood cholesterol as well.  She wants some support with some dietary recommendations to assist both of them in healthier eating.  The two of them live alone now, and she is used to cooking for large portions.  She is having a hard time adjusting to preparing food for the two of them.  She would like to do less food preparation, in fact.  She is starting a new job this week.

patient_descriptions.patient_statement: You have an infection of the urinary tract.  I knew it was an I U T. I have already had it, but nothing so painful and severe. I feel like I'm going to die! Doctor: Oh yes, it's because you have something called acute cystitis and its usually very painful and can cause serious complications.  Well, is it because of my diabetes? Doctor: I'm afraid I don't have any better news for you, but your diabetes is out of control. It's way too high and you need to be really careful. Do you take your medication?  Yes! Doctor: How to eat?  Yes, sometimes I don't care about my diet. Doctor: Well, you have to monitor your diet, you can't just be careless. I'm going to change your treatment for diabetes. And let yourself take care of the antibiotic that should relieve you.
patient_descriptions.context: Diabetes type II uncontrolled.  Acute cystitis.

patient_descriptions.patient_statement: Doctor: Do you remember when your last influenza vaccine was?  I don't remember what month, but it was in nineteen-nine. Doctor: Good, and you remember your last vaccine against pneumonia?  Let me look at my notes here, um, it was in nineteen-sixteen. Doctor: Thank you, now tell me about your parents. Do you know their medical history?  Let me think, my father is still there, he had a stroke. Oh yes, and he has high blood pressure. Doctor: How old is your father?  He is seventy-nine years old now. Doctor: Good, and your mother?  She died when she was seventy-four years old, she had a heart failure and an emhysema. Doctor: I'm sorry to hear that. Do you have brothers or sisters?  Thank you doctor, no, he's my only father and I now.
patient_descriptions.context: Last flu vaccine was given on 1999. Last pneumonia vaccine was given on 1996. Family Medical History: Father age 79, history of cerebrovascular accident (stroke) and hypertension. Mother history of CHF and emphysema that died at the age of 74. No brothers and sisters.

patient_descriptions.patient_statement: Doctor: I have had side effects. Doctor: Have you had side effects?  No, not yet. Doctor: Good, can you describe your erections for me, sir?  Well, they were firm now, and I can enter again for about ten minutes. Doctor: Well, do you have chest pain?  No sir, I stopped using my nitroglycerin too. Doctor: Good, do you have fever or chills?  No, nothing like that. Doctor: Do you have pains with urination, or blood in the urine?  No, nothing like that, sir, everything is normal. Doctor: How many times do you urinate during the day?  No, nothing like that. Doctor: Do you have pains with urine, or blood in the urine?  No, nothing like that, sir, everything is normal.
patient_descriptions.context: The patient presents today for followup, history of erectile dysfunction, last visit started on Cialis 10 mg.  He indicates that he has noticed some mild improvement of his symptoms, with no side effect.  On this dose, he is having firm erection, able to penetrate, lasting for about 10 or so minutes.  No chest pain, no nitroglycerin usage, no fever, no chills.  No dysuria, gross hematuria, fever, chills.  Daytime frequency every three hours, nocturia times 0, good stream.  He does have a history of elevated PSA and biopsy June of this year was noted for high grade PIN, mid left biopsy, with two specimens being too small to evaluate.  PSA 11.6.  Dr. X's notes are reviewed.

patient_descriptions.patient_statement: Doctor: Have you ever had any heart problems in the past?  I remember that I had something heart, but I don't know what it was. I don't understand the medical terms. Doctor: Okay, that's good, I totally understand. We'll try to look for your medical history.  I have hypertension and diabetes, you know that well? Doctor: Yes, type 2 diabetes. Do you know any other things you've had in the past?  Yes, four years later I had a pulmonary embolism. I also get frequent infections in the urine. Doctor: Ok. And I can see on the record that you have a high cholesterol level and a gastric ulcer too.  Yes, that's pretty right. Doctor: Ok. What surgery did you have in the past?  I've had my appendix, then Section C, cataract surgery and repair of hernia in the past.
patient_descriptions.context: She has had a fairly extensive past medical history but is a somewhat poor historian and is unable to provide details about her history.  She states that she has underlying history of heart disease but is not able to elaborate to any significant extent.  She also has a history of hypertension and type II diabetes but is not currently taking any medication.  She has also had a history of pulmonary embolism approximately four years ago, hyperlipidemia, peptic ulcer disease, and recurrent urinary tract infections.  Surgeries include an appendectomy, cesarean section, cataracts, and hernia repair.

patient_descriptions.patient_statement: Good morning, doctor.
patient_descriptions.context: The patient is a 14-year-old male who reported having knee pain for 1 month.  Apparently while he was playing basketball on 12/22/2007 when he had gone up for a jump, he felt a pop in his knee.  The patient was seen at an outside facility where he was splinted and subsequently referred to Children's for definitive care.  Radiographs confirmed comminuted tibial tubercle avulsion fracture with patella alta.  Surgery is recommended to the grandmother and subsequently to the father by phone.  Surgery would consist of open reduction and internal fixation with subsequent need for later hardware removal.  Risks of surgery include the risks of  anesthesia, infection, bleeding, changes on sensation in most of the extremity, hardware failure, need for later hardware removal, failure to restore extensor mechanism tension, and need for postoperative rehab.  All questions were answered, and father and grandmother agreed to the above plan.

patient_descriptions.patient_statement: Doctor: Do you have problems like headache, fever, rash, mouth ulcer?  None. Doctor: A problem with vision? As unable to see or double vision?  Um no, I can see everything. Doctor: Okay. Do you have palpitations, as you know about your own heart?  No, nothing like that. Doctor: What about breathlessness while you lie down or you have to get up in the middle of the night to breathe? Pattor: No, I don't feel anything like it lately. Pattor: It's great. Any diarrhea, constipation, or red blood coming out in the stools? Or pale stools? Like any change in the color of the stools? Pattor: No, it's okay. Doctor: All right. Any jaundice recently?  No. No. No jaundice. Doctor: Do you have appetite problems?  Yes, I want to say less that you are hungry.
patient_descriptions.context: No rashes, headache, photophobia, diplopia, or oral ulcers. No palpitations, orthopnea or PND. No diarrhea, constipation, melena, bright red blood per rectum, or pale stool. No jaundice. Decreased appetite, but no weight loss.

patient_descriptions.patient_statement: Doctor: Hello, I am Dr James. Guest_family: Hello Doctor, this is my daughter Miya, and I am Jena. Doctor: Nice to meet you ladies. So, Miya, how old are you?  I am fifteen years old. Doctor: Okay, then tell me what's going on with you?  Well, I have serious headaches. Guest_family: She has been complaining about it for almost six hours now. Doctor: Oh wow. Can you tell me exactly where the pain is?  Um, it started from my neck and then it went up to the back of my head. Doctor: I see. Did you get hurt or hit in the head?  No. Doctor: Can she have a history of headaches? Guest_family: No. Doctor: All right, nausea or vomiting?  I have nausea, but it's going without vomiting. Also, I can't tolerate the light at all? Doctor: Are you capable of seeing any fever? Doctor: Are you correctly? Doctor: Are you able to see all?
patient_descriptions.context: This is a 15-year-old girl presenting with occipital headache for the last six hours.  She denies trauma.  She has been intermittently nauseated but has not vomited and has some photophobia.  Denies fever or change in vision.  She has no past history of headaches.

patient_descriptions.patient_statement: Doctor: How do you feel?  I feel good. Doctor: Any illness or fever?  No, nothing like that. Doctor: Any headache or nausea?  No. Doctor: Any vomiting or upset stomach?  No. Doctor: All right, all numbness tingling or loss of sensation in the hand?  No, not at all. Doctor: Otherwise feel good?  Yes.
patient_descriptions.context: Otherwise well.  No febrile illness.  No motor or sensory complaints of any sort or paresthesias in the hand.

patient_descriptions.patient_statement: What?
patient_descriptions.context: The patient is a pleasant but demented 80-year-old male, who lives in board and care, who presented with acute onset of abdominal pain.  In the emergency room, the patient was found to have a CT scan with dilated bladder with thick wall suggesting an outlet obstruction as well as bilateral hydronephrosis and hydroureter.  The patient is unable to provide further history.  The patient's son is at the bedside and confirmed his history.  The patient was given IV antibiotics in the emergency room.  He was also given some hydration.

patient_descriptions.patient_statement: He's kidding. I know my name. I also know his kids' names. I do agree that sometimes I forget my things or feel lost.

patient_descriptions.patient_statement: Doctor: What's going on with you today?  Oh, I have chest pain. Doctor: You have fever too?  Yes, I did.
patient_descriptions.context: Chest pain and fever.

patient_descriptions.patient_statement: Oh doc, I've had a lot of trouble breathing lately. Doctor: I'm sorry to hear that. We're going to get to the bottom.  Yes, I'm losing my breath so quickly with only one to two flights of stairs. Doctor: When did you start to notice that?  I think two weeks ago. Doctor: Any chest pain or oppression with breathlessness?  No, fortunately. Doctor: Any fever, chills or sweats?  No. Doctor: Any cough or cough of blood?  No. Doctor: What would you say to whistle or swelling in your legs?  No.
patient_descriptions.context: Dyspnea on exertion.  No chest pain or tightness, fever, chills, sweats, cough, hemoptysis, or wheeze, or lower extremity swelling.

patient_descriptions.patient_statement: I'm thirteen, sir.
patient_descriptions.context: The patient is a 13-year-old right-hand dominant girl, who fell off a swing at school around 1:30 today.  The patient was initially seen at an outside facility and brought here by her father, given findings on x-ray, a closed reduction was attempted on the left elbow.  After the attempted reduction, the patient was noted to have an incarcerated medial epicondyle fracture as well as increasing ulnar paresthesias that were not present prior to the procedure.  Given this finding, the patient needed urgent open reduction and internal fixation to relieve the pressure on the ulnar nerve.  At that same time, the patient's mildly angulated radial shaft fracture will be reduced.  This was explained to the father.  The risks of surgery included the risk of anesthesia, infection, bleeding, changes in sensation and motion of the extremity, hardware failure, need for later hardware removal, and possible continuous nerve symptoms.  All questions were answered.  The father agreed to the above plan.
