patient_descriptions.patient_statement: Doctor: A muscle pain?  No, not really. Doctor: A problem in walking? Pattor: No, it's normal. Doctor: Let me check your toes and fingers. Can you move them for me? Pattor: Yes. Doctor: Everything looks good. Nails seems good too. No bluish discoloration any signs of infection. Can you push your legs against my hand. Pattor: Both legs? Pattor: Yes, both. Well, your muscle strength is equal and stable in both legs, so it's good. Motion seems right. Doctor: Any tenderness? Pattor: No. Doctor: And I don't see any swelling or accumulation of fluid. Pattor: Ok.
patient_descriptions.context: MSK: Normal gait and station.  No pathology to digits or nails.  Extremities move times four.  No tenderness or effusion.  Range of motion adequate.  Strength and tone equal bilaterally, stable.

patient_descriptions.patient_statement: Doctor: How do you feel? Have you been sick?  Yes, I do not feel well for the last three days. I have a pain in the body, cough and throat. Doctor: Do you have the wet cough or it is dry? What color the sputum comes out?  It is wet and green things of color comes out. Doctor: Okay, we will have to send them to the culture, maybe an infection. Doctor: How about fever, chills, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea something like that? Are you sleeping well?  Everything is fine except a few chills? I sleep well. Doctor: Do you need anything for cough?  I don't need anything for cough. I called yesterday and I received a refill of my keflex. Then I took two keflex this morning and I feel a little better now. Doctor: Okay then why are you crying, ma'am?  I'm just feeling tired: I'm sorry. I'm just feeling tired: I'm sorry.
patient_descriptions.context: XYZ is in today not feeling well for the last three days.  She is a bit sick with bodyaches.  She is coughing.  She has a sore throat, especially when she coughs.  Her cough is productive of green colored sputum.  She has had some chills.  No vomiting.  No diarrhea.  She is sleeping okay.  She does not feel like she needs anything for the cough.  She did call in yesterday, and got a refill of her Keflex.  She took two Keflex this morning and she is feeling a little bit better now.  She is tearful, just tired of feeling ran down.

patient_descriptions.patient_statement: Doctor: Do you take anything for acid reflux?  Yes, I take Aciphex. Doctor: Is 20 M G once a day?  It is. I also take a baby Aspirin in the morning.
patient_descriptions.context: Aciphex 20 mg q.d. and aspirin 81 mg q.d.

patient_descriptions.patient_statement: Doctor: You are seventy years old, that's right?  When did you begin to feel joint pain?  A few years ago.  How did it worsen?  He made me less active in general. My hands and wrists aren't as mobile. Doctor: Have you noticed an increase in swelling?  No, but everything has become a little too uncomfortable. Doctor: I see here that you are taking Daypro's credits. Does that help?  No. Doctor: And no redness in the bathroom, right?  No. Doctor: Fever or chills?  I had diarrhea for a few days, but it went much better. I also had trouble holding my bladder.
patient_descriptions.context: A 77-year-old white female who is having more problems with joint pain.  It seems to be all over decreasing her mobility, hands and wrists.  No real swelling but maybe just a little more uncomfortable than they have been.  The Daypro generic does not seem to be helping at all.  No fever or chills.  No erythema. She actually is doing better.  Her diarrhea now has settled down and she is having less urinary incontinence, less pedal edema.  Blood sugars seem to be little better as well. The patient also has gotten back on her Zoloft because she thinks she may be depressed, sleeping all the time, just not herself and really is disturbed that she cannot be more mobile in things.  She has had no polyuria, polydipsia, or other problems.  No recent blood pressure checks.

patient_descriptions.patient_statement: Doctor: Where did it hurt you?  Ah, my upper part of the chest and it turned all around my right side up to my back. Doctor: Okay, how do you feel now?  I feel very weak and tired, I don't feel like doing anything other than rest. Doctor: Any fever?  Yes, the nurse just took my temperature at 100 points three. Doctor: Okay. Did you have these symptoms before?  No, the first time. I never felt like that. Doctor: Okay. You had chills or chills?  No. Doctor: When did you have your last intestinal movement?  It was yesterday. Doctor: Did you notice blood in your stools or a rectum bleeding?  No. Doctor: How old are you?  I am twenty-eight years old. Doctor: And you had a gastric bypass, one year ago.  Yes, almost a year ago.
patient_descriptions.context: The patient is a 28-year-old, who is status post gastric bypass surgery nearly one year ago.  He has lost about 200 pounds and was otherwise doing well until yesterday evening around 7:00-8:00 when he developed nausea and right upper quadrant pain, which apparently wrapped around toward his right side and back.  He feels like he was on it but has not done so.  He has overall malaise and a low-grade temperature of 100.3.  He denies any prior similar or lesser symptoms.  His last normal bowel movement was yesterday.  He denies any outright chills or blood per rectum.

patient_descriptions.patient_statement: Doctor: I have to ask you a few questions.  Of course. Doctor: Do you feel weakness or fatigue?  No. Doctor: No malaise or disease?  No, nothing like this. Doctor: No chill or high temperature?  No. Doctor: Any excessive sweating or night sweating?  Um, no. Doctor: How about allergies, are you allergic to anything?  No, no allergies. Doctor: Very good.
patient_descriptions.context: GENERAL: Negative weakness, negative fatigue, native malaise, negative chills, negative fever, negative night sweats, negative allergies.

patient_descriptions.patient_statement: Doctor: You don't look so good today. What's the problem?  Well, I'm having trouble. My whole body hurts and I'm in pain. Doctor: Do you have a history of drug use?  Well, yes. I'm detoxing. Doctor: What kind of medication have you taken?  Hero. Doctor: How long have you been using?  I don't feel well. Maybe a year. I can't sleep or eat. Doctor: Have you had fever, chills, vomiting or diarrhea?  I think I have fever. I feel cold. I had diarrhea.
patient_descriptions.context: Detox from heroin.

patient_descriptions.patient_statement: Doctor: Oh doctor, you flatter me. I'm sixty-two years old. Doctor: Great, and you've already had a rotator wrist repair, that's right?  Yes, that's right. Doctor: Well, well, what seems to be the problem today?  I still have a lot of pain in this shoulder. Doctor: Oh no, did you have a recent imaging done on this shoulder?  Yes, I had an MR I didn't have too long, can you take a look at it? I have it here. Doctor: Thank you, yes, this MR I show that you still tore the rotator handle.  Oh no, can we do another operation to fix it again? Doctor: Yes, we will have to.  What is the risk of infection of surgery? Doctor: It's less than one percent.
patient_descriptions.context: This is a 62-year-old female who previously underwent a repair of rotator cuff.  She continued to have pain within the shoulder.  She had a repeat MRI performed, which confirmed the clinical diagnosis of re-tear of the rotator cuff.  She wished to proceed with a repair.  All risks and benefits of the surgery were discussed with her at length.  She was in agreement with the above treatment plan.

patient_descriptions.patient_statement: I'm Dr. Welch. Guest_family: Thank you! It's nice to meet you. Doctor: How old is your daughter? Guest_family: She's three years old now. Doctor: Hello!  Hello! Doctor: Mom I would like to start with some questions about pregnancy, childbirth, and previous children. Guest_family: Do you have any other children? Guest_family: No. It's my only child. Doctor: Have you ever had any miscarriages or abortions before you had your daughter? Guest_family: I had a very young miscarriage before I was pregnant with her. Doctor: I'm sorry to hear that. Guest_family: Thank you. I was difficult but when I got pregnant with her, we were so happy. Doctor: Did you have any difficulties or problems during your pregnancy. Guest_family: I had the flu in my seventh or eighth month of pregnancy.
patient_descriptions.context: Spontaneous Vaginal delivery at 36weeks gestation to a G2P1 mother. Birth weight 7#10oz. No instrumentation required. Labor = 11hours. "Light gas anesthesia" given. Apgars unknown. Mother reportedly had the "flu" in the 7th or 8th month of gestation. Patient discharged 5 days post-partum. Development: spoke first words between 1 and 2 years of age. Rolled side to side at age 2, but did not walk. Fed self with hands at age 2 years. Never toilet trained.

patient_descriptions.patient_statement: Doctor: Of course, I'm seventy-nine years old. Doctor: Well, thank you. What is the problem today, madam?  Well, I have this arthritis, as you know. Doctor: Yes, how would you describe your arthritis?  Well, at this stage, I would say it's debilitating. Doctor: I see, so anti-inflammatory and rest didn't help at all?  No, I haven't had any improvement, Doctor. It's still so bad. Doctor: I see, I think you would be a good candidate for a knee replacement.  Yes, I thought so. What are the risks of infection for surgery? Doctor: Uh, it's less than one percent, we use prophylaxis antibiotics to control infection all the time.  It's great, and about anesthesia, am I going to sleep for that? Doctor: Yes, you haven't experienced surgery, I want to.
patient_descriptions.context: This is a 79-year-old female who has disabling bilateral knee degenerative arthritis.  She has been unresponsive to conservative measures.  All risks, complications, anticipated benefits, and postoperative course were discussed.  The patient has agreed to proceed with surgery as described below.

patient_descriptions.patient_statement: Doctor: You have plans to follow up and remove staples in a week with Dr. X Y Z. Do you have any instructions for wound care?  Yes. Doctor: Do you have any questions?  No. Doctor: If you have any questions or concerns that may arise, do not hesitate to call the office.  OK. Doctor: If you develop a fever greater than one hundred and one point four, chills, nausea, vomiting, or persistent diarrhea, please call the office.
patient_descriptions.context: The patient was instructed to contact us with any questions or concerns that may arise.  In addition, he was instructed to contact us, if he would have fevers greater than 101.4, chills, nausea or vomitting, continuing diarrhea, redness, drainage, or warmth around his incision site.  He will be seen in about one week's time in Dr. XYZ's clinic and his staples will be removed at that time.

patient_descriptions.patient_statement: Doctor: Because it's more allergic.  Okay. Doctor: So we call it allergic rhinitis.  Is it different from sinus infection? Doctor: Yes, it's different.  Okay.
patient_descriptions.context: I think this is still his allergic rhinitis rather than a sinus infection.

patient_descriptions.patient_statement: Doctor: So, to check, you have a history of hay fever and asthma, right?  Yes. I was also recently diagnosed with cervical dysplasia. I discovered shortly after my last visit O B G Y N. Doctor: And do you intend to follow your O B G Y N in the coming months?  Yes, the next visit is scheduled and everything.
patient_descriptions.context: Significant for asthma, allergic rhinitis and cervical dysplasia.

patient_descriptions.patient_statement: I agree with Dr. Jones that your lungs show no signs of infection or loss of lung capacity.  OK.
patient_descriptions.context: Chest x-ray ordered by ER physician is unremarkable, but to me also.

patient_descriptions.patient_statement: Good morning, I'm sixty five years old, doctor.
patient_descriptions.context: The patient is a 65-year-old female who underwent left upper lobectomy for stage IA non-small cell lung cancer.  She returns for a routine surveillance visit. She has undergone since her last visit an abdominopelvic CT, which shows an enlarging simple cyst of the left kidney.  She underwent barium swallow, which demonstrates a small sliding hiatal hernia with minimal reflux.  She has a minimal delayed emptying secondary tertiary contractions.  PA and lateral chest x-ray from the 11/23/09 was also reviewed, which demonstrates no lesions or infiltrates.  Review of systems, the patient continues to have periodic odynophagia and mid thoracic dysphagia.  This most likely is secondary to tertiary contractions with some delayed emptying.  She has also had increased size of the left calf without tenderness, which has not resolved over the past several months.  She has had a previous DVT in 1975 and 1985.  She denies weight loss, anorexia, fevers, chills, headaches, new aches or pains, cough, hemoptysis, shortness of breath at rest, or dyspnea on exertion.
